articles.headline: For Tribune Buyer, a Storm to the West
articles.snippet: The Los Angeles Times, a problem for Tribune, may be even more of a challenge for its new owner, Samuel Zell.
articles.abstract: The Los Angeles Times, a problem for Tribune, may be even more of a challenge for its new owner, Samuel Zell.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, April 2 — The Los Angeles Times was nothing but trouble for the Tribune Company, and it may prove even more of a challenge for its new owner, Samuel Zell.
articles.byline: By Laura M. Holson and Sharon Waxman

articles.headline: U.S. and South Korea in Landmark Trade Deal
articles.snippet: The deal gives the U.S. a lift to its trade policy and South Korea a chance to reinvigorate its export economy.
articles.abstract: The deal gives the U.S. a lift to its trade policy and South Korea a chance to reinvigorate its export economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea, April 2 — United States and South Korean negotiators struck the world’s largest bilateral free trade agreement on Monday, giving the United States a badly needed lift to its trade policy at home and South Korea a chance to reinvigorate its export economy.

articles.headline: Chicagoan Puts Up $315 Million to Win $8.2 Billion Tribune Co.
articles.snippet: Tribune has joined forces with Samuel Zell to take the company private and pay shareholders $34 a share.
articles.abstract: Tribune has joined forces with Samuel Zell to take the company private and pay shareholders $34 a share.
articles.lead_paragraph: How did a Chicago real estate tycoon win one of the country’s premier media companies — a chain of big-city papers, two dozen television stations and the Chicago Cubs — in a deal valued at $8.2 billion with an investment of only $315 million of his own money?
articles.byline: By Katharine Q. Seelye and Richard Siklos

articles.headline: EMI to Drop Digital Locks in Web Sales
articles.snippet: In a significant shift, EMI will sell songs online through Apple’s music service without copy protection.
articles.abstract: In a significant shift, EMI will sell songs online through Apple’s music service without copy protection.
articles.lead_paragraph: EMI Group, the British music giant, broke ranks with the music industry’s biggest corporations yesterday by announcing a deal to sell songs online through Apple’s music service without copy protection.

articles.headline: Romney Reaps $20 Million to Top G.O.P. Rivals
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign tapped two distant networks — Wall Street and the Mormon Church — to outpace his rivals in the first quarter.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign tapped two distant networks — Wall Street and the Mormon Church — to outpace his rivals in the first quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 2 — Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign said Monday that it had raised $20 million in the first quarter, tapping two distant but rich networks — Wall Street and the Mormon Church — to easily outpace his better-known Republican primary rivals.

articles.headline: McCain Wrong on Iraq Security, Merchants Say
articles.snippet: Iraqis disputed assertions by the senator’s delegation that a Baghdad market they visited was safe.
articles.abstract: Iraqis disputed assertions by the senator’s delegation that a Baghdad market they visited was safe.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, April 2 — A day after members of an American Congressional delegation led by Senator John McCain pointed to their brief visit to Baghdad’s central market as evidence that the new security plan for the city was working, the merchants there were incredulous about the Americans’ conclusions.

articles.headline: A New Owner Who Is Hedging His Bets
articles.snippet: Taking Tribune private will ease quarterly earnings pressures, but operational challenges will remain.
articles.abstract: Taking Tribune private will ease quarterly earnings pressures, but operational challenges will remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a self-published little red booklet entitled “Quotations from the Chairman,” Samuel Zell, the real estate magnate who often sounds like a thoughtful version of Yosemite Sam, offered this guidance: “Be a risk taker; however, define risk by your own terms.”

articles.headline: After 2000 Loss, Obama Built Donor Network From Roots Up
articles.snippet: In many ways, Barack Obama has built a quite conventional money machine.
articles.abstract: In many ways, Barack Obama has built a quite conventional money machine.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When Barack Obama announced to friends over brunch in 2002 that he planned to run for the United States Senate, one of their first questions was how he could possibly raise the necessary millions.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: Home Lender Is Seeking Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: New Century Financial became the biggest, and most prominent, corporate failure in the subprime mortgage business.
articles.abstract: New Century Financial became the biggest, and most prominent, corporate failure in the subprime mortgage business.
articles.lead_paragraph: From an 11-story steel-and-glass tower that housed its headquarters in Irvine, Calif., the New Century Financial Corporation ruled as one of the nation’s largest mortgage lenders to individuals with weak, or subprime, credit during the recent housing boom.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Vikas Bajaj
